notes.title: Acute Coronary Syndrome
notes.content: ACS encompasses unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI. STEMI requires ST elevation ≥1mm in 2 contiguous leads or ≥2mm in precordial leads. Troponins rise 3-4 hours post-injury, peak at 24-48 hours, and remain elevated for 7-14 days.

notes.title: Heart Failure Basics
notes.content: BNP >100 pg/mL suggests heart failure. Ejection fraction classification: HFpEF (≥50%), mildly reduced (41-49%), moderately reduced (31-40%), HFrEF (≤30%). HFrEF is systolic dysfunction with dilated ventricle. HFpEF is diastolic dysfunction with stiff ventricle.

cards.front: What are the ECG criteria for STEMI diagnosis?
cards.back: ≥1mm ST elevation in 2 contiguous leads OR ≥2mm in precordial leads OR new LBBB in clinical context

cards.front: When do troponins peak after myocardial injury?
cards.back: Peak at 24-48 hours (rise at 3-4 hours, remain elevated 7-14 days)

cards.front: What BNP level suggests heart failure?

cards.back: EF ≤40% (some guidelines use ≤30% for severe HFrEF)
